description: Numbers n such that every difference between consecutive divisors (ordered by increasing magnitude) of n is also a divisor of n.
comments: Equivalently, A060763(n)=0.Powers of 2 and factorials up to 7! are here.For each k=1..A000005(a(n))-1 exists k' < A000005(a(n)) such that A193829(a(n),k) = A027750(a(n),k'). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 25 2015
links: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..750
example: For n = 12, divisors={1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12}; differences={1, 1, 1, 2, 6}; every difference is a divisor, so 12 is in the sequence.
prog: (Haskell)import Data.List (sort, nub); import Data.List.Ordered (subset)a060765 n = a060765_list !! (n-1)a060765_list = filter   (\x -> sort (nub $ a193829_row x) `subset` a027750_row' x) [1..]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 25 2015
author: _Labos Elemer_, Apr 24 2001
